column4: did quake work on unity/class and no longer when you installed gnome-shell?
correct
have you checked the logs for any type of error , or possibly tried starting it from a terminal to debug the output?
I haven't, I will restart my machine and check for logs
you can do that, you can also run quake from a terminal prompt and see if it gives any clues
I run guake manually and it works though. Keep that in mind
interesting
it just doesn't start - up
ok, brb
it is, it doesn't load with all other startup applications
you mean to bring it down?
no, it's F1
the process is now running because I started it with Alt+F2
it doesn't start on bootup
ok, I'll be back,
nope, didn't startup
1871 pts/0    S+     0:00 grep --color=auto guake
maybe you can try to collect some details on the job and redirect it to a log on start up so you can get an idea of whats going on?
how do I do that?
oh boy, that's magic to me
but you would want to make that your startup line, so you get it when the issue is occuring
I entered it into the terminal and guake started
thats what we expected no? the issue you want to trace is startup
so adjust your startup command to be that command posted last, and reboot
I see, brb then
lets see the line before you go.. just in case
sudo strace -o /var/log/guake.log guake
how about gksudo
I see
I can sudo without password, is that what you're asking about?
I always sudo visudo with NOPASSWD, I hate that password shit
lol
su laptop strace -o /var/log/guake.log guake ?
I'm confused now, please write the whole line
as it should be
yes
ok, now reboot, brb
so what now

if its there and populated, take your time looking through it, if there is a obvious error you should see it, be wary of directory/file not found as it traverses your $PATH entries, those are somewhat normal
let me see
that thing has almost 13 thousand lines
thats not surprising at all
there are filters you can use to slim it up, but in this case, we dont know what the issue is so better to have it all
some clever usage of grep and negation will help you
Jesus, it will take me forever, and I don't even know what to look for
what's that? : read(7, "timeError(\"Refusing to create an"..., 4096) = 3049
laptop@ubuntu:/var/log$ cat guake.log | grep error
it says IO Error, is that the case?
no?
one second.. looking something up for you..
ok, I'm sorry
hmmm, so should I do something to Python? Sounds like a story from zoo
read(6, "error, \"unterminated name\"\n     "..., 4096) = 4096 it seems it hits this error in the python code before sys.exit is called (gracefully one would say) from python
not sure if changing python is wise yet,, did something change with it and the update? or some dependant library?
you can also google this and see if it is common
but how come does guake start when called for from Alt+F2?
I guess I'm too dumb in this field.
maybe it depends on something that is not available at the time it's being brought up?
can I delay the startup ?
i was actually going to say try that,, but it would be like "random" and it may not do anything at all
let's delay it for 10s, what would be the spell?
Ok, let me reboot, let's see.
nope
hmph
Ok, no worries, I thank you for the time you sacrificed here for me.
well that wasn't really any type of good solution anyway the sleep thing
no worries
save your log. if you find its a legitimate issue, maybe you can use it to file a report with the guake team
I know, I just hung upon that thing where you said it maybe depended on something that started up later.
I will
that still may be the case
sometimes sleep won't cut it,, especially with upstart and such starting things asynch
where did you learn all that stuff?
been an admin/engineer for a few years, now i automate these things
lol, maybe, you're good though
thanks a lot ;>
I should be thanking you.
I'll find another terminal that will work, I think terminator can do slide down too...

im sure there are alternatives,, terminator is my fav at the moment it doesn't do slide down, i swear i recall some drawn out process of making it seem like it did though,, thats most likely invalidated by unity/gnome-shell (this was back in the day)
aaah, I see
another thing you can try is to look for an updated package or such like check your version and see if the dev's have a later stable version with bug fixes etc
let me do that now
is there a shortcut "about" kind of thing in terminal I can run to look at any application that's installed? Or do I have to do apt-cache?
apt-cache show
worked lol
awesome
can I somehow return the favor for your help?
nah - im used to support and stuff no sweat at all - i fear to say i like to help people?
I installed tilda terminal, let's see if this one will startup , brb
this one works perfectly
